repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body: TODO: This puts the cursor in new line. How can we avoid that?

@UtkarshMe The text that is to be displayed on the same line should be passed here as the second argument. You will need to add an argument to `get_number` so `prompt_for_number` and `ml_recover` can send this string in.
Although this does not process any alphabets, it does process special characters. (but they get filtered in `get_number`). Is there a macro which checks for special characters?
should either be its own history or `HIST_INVALID`
isn't it better to check if it is a digit?
I don't think langmap should be invoked (so remove this).

The existing shenanigans with `cmdfirstc` is a bit unfortunate... `get_cmdline_type()` should support the new `#` type. Either a boolean flag for this type needs to be added in `ccline`, or perhaps better variable that is the unadulterated `s->firstc` value (to support future expansion), which probably also should be used in `get_histtype`
I thought of it too, but then `CTRL_C`, `K_SELECT` etc are also ignored.
Roger that.
Ok, why isn't `ccline.cmdfirstc = s->firstc` simply? Why make it 0 for '@'?

Got it. This has to be 0 for both '@' and '#' because it is the first character shown on the command line.

So we keep it 0 for both
**OR** we can change all the `cmdfirstc == NUL` checks. (maybe open another pull request for it?)
well, then this check should be moved to after special chars are checked, and just before a char is inserted into the cmdline string.

I'm not sure this change is good or not. IIRC emtpy firstc should only occur with `input()` so there is no strong reason to change it (and if not, we should consider setting firstc in that other place instead)

Also, in this file a test should be added that `inputlist()` works as expected with external cmdline (firstc is set to `#`, prompt if applicable)
Then also, we should consider allowing GUI:s to convert `inputlist()` in to proper dialogs. That would be a separate follow up PR though (so no action needed here)

I think we already use `@` for setting the mode for `input()` function in `getcmdline()` and the likes, so while adding `#` which also uses `input()` function, it seemed better to use `@` as `firstc` to distinguish between the two.

Not sure i follow, only `input()` is `input()` (well, except for `inputdialog()` for the moment). Number (`inputlist()` ) is a new and different cmdline type, and should definitely be marked with `firstc = '#'` (even if prompt is available, we will need to update the docs). I was speaking if some other cmdline type  also happened to set `firstc = ""` already (maybe some ex mode state), it is probably much rarer and so nicer to clients to change that instead.

Oh, I get it now! There is another mode `:insert` with `firstc = NUL`. The line `ccline.cmdfirstc = (firstc == '@' ? 0 : firstc)` makes `cmdfirstc` for both `:insert` and `input()` same, but I guess that's because they are so similar.
I think I understand it now and should revert back to `firstc = ""` for `@` mode.

Yes `:append` /`:insert` should maybe be marked with `-`, but overall ex mode commands will not look good with ext-ui so this could be considered in a later PR (where "later" could mean "never", if the intersection of users using ex mode and extended UI is empty, which is not impossible)
Hmm cursor position is weird, ideally it should be on the first column, or perhaps avoid the last blank line altogether if possible.

comment_data.body:
Most handling of special chars can be removed from this loop.

We probably still want to support selection by mouse in this mode. Look at `case K_MOUSELEFT` in `command_line_handle_key`, where `#` mode should be special cased. (replacing the text with the number printed as a string is fine)

I think you can use `TV_LIST_ITEM_NEXT(list, li) != NULL` to check if an item is last and then avoid the `msg_putchar('\n')`. ( when `ui_is_external(kUICmdline)` is true)

Alternatively, i think you can just add an `msg_putchar('\r')` at the end to move it back to first column.

comment_data.body: Better to check against equality to `tv_list_last()`: it makes the intention more clear.

comment_data.body:
Good question, previously mouse works in `inputlist()` if the mode from which it was called was included in `set mouse`, but now it will be controlled by if `mouse=c` (or `a`, which is the default) is included. We could add an exception so that mouse is always active with `firstc='#'` unless `mouse` is completely empty. (this will also require change to `setmouse()`). For now, you can start with it working with `mouse=c` or `a`, so put the condition _after_ this if block.

if `s->firstc == '#'` you will need to check if the mouse is above the cmdline row, and then `return 0` to abort the cmdline. But you need to somehow signal back to  `get_number` that mouse was used (so that it reads `mouse_row` instead), as `getcmdline_prompt` is not called much, adding a `bool *` out arg would be fine.

Hi, sorry for the late reply (acads in college), how do I test if mouse is working? I tried to use mouse to select options in Kitty, Gnome Terminal and Tilda but it did not work in any (even in the master branch)... Which terminal can I use to test mouse?
What does `set mouse` give? Try `set mouse=a` . The two first I know should work, if still not, what is `$TERM` ?
Ok! So so sorry for this... I had not set mouse. :sweat_smile:

I think we should avoid storing pointers globally if not necessary. Instead set the return value in `getcmdline_prompt` after `getcmdline`. Also place the value inside `ccline`, not globally. (if mouse support is conditional, an explicit bool variable is also better than a NULL check far from where the pointer is defined)
After rebasing with master, if `msg_putchar('\n')` is not present after every list item, the list isn't displayed correctly. Should I revert?

comment_data.body: I don't think this should be added (it seems to mostly used for expansion)
can use CALLBACK_NONE in arg list and drop `input_callback`
inputlist
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -36,6 +36,7 @@ typedef enum {
   HIST_SEARCH,        ///< Search commands.
   HIST_EXPR,          ///< Expressions (e.g. from entering = register).
   HIST_INPUT,         ///< input() lines.
+  HIST_INPUT_NUM,     ///< input() numbers.

comment_data.body: We probably only want to do this for press events, not DRAG or RELEASE (it should then fallthrough to the ordinary code below)

Something like this?
```c
if (s->firstc == '#' && mouse_row < cmdline_row && s->ignore_drag_release)
```
It does solve the problem of returning as soon as mouse is pressed. It returns after mouse is released.

I don't think that is a problem, activation on press is expected. The situation is rather to press mouse at cmdline (which moves the cursor), and then accidentially drag over the second last line, which should continue to move the cursor, not accept the last choice.
After the change mentioned above, if you drag over the second last line from the cmdline, it won't be accepted but if you release while on it, it will be. Is this the expected behavior?
hmm I will try it
To me it feels a bit weird, better to introduce `bool is_press = s->c == K_LEFTMOUSE || s->c == K_RIGHTMOUSE` and use it.

comment_regular_data.body: cc @ZyX-I @bfredl

It's because that line is not echoed as a message anymore. It is unrelated to what the test tests (that nvim doesn't crash or behave weirdly with NULL list), so just update the test to the new behavior.

@bfredl I need help... the log messages say that legacy tests are failing but `make oldtest` is successful on my system (`ALL DONE`).

Also, QuickBuild has these two failures for `functionaltest-macosx-64-debug`:
- timers can be stopped
- timers can be stopped from the handler
functional tests pass on my system (`Linux 4.15.5-1-ARCH`).
Timer tests are known to be fragile, can ignore them for now. Though with oldtests, at least the ASAN build it looks like it has detected a memory leak.

TODO:
- [x] Add UI ext-cmdline test for `inputlist()`

The test `test/functional/ui/cmdline_spec.lua` passes locally but not on Travis.
This is the error:
```
Expected:
  |*{1:~                        }|
  |{1:~                        }|
  |{1:~                        }|
  |input0                   |
  |input1^                   |
Actual:
  |*                         |
  |{1:~                        }|
  |{3:                         }|
  |input0                   |
  |input1^                   |
```
Please rebase on master and try again locally, there was a change on master how multiline messages are displayed, this looks like it could be it.

Seems to work pretty well now. A bit more tests would be good (without ext_cmdline, can be in `ui/input_spec.lua`), for instance:
- type number and CR
- type number and ESC
- type alphabetical chars
- mouse usage (in tests use `feed('<LeftMouse><col,row>')`, see `ui/mouse_spec.lua` for examples)
Do you think it will be better to create a new file `ui/inputlist_spec.lua` or adding to `ui/input_spec.lua` is fine?
Actually, `eval/inputlist_spec.lua` would make most sense.

`:h inputlist` shows that "clicking on the prompt one more than the length is returned".
But in this pull request, clicking on prompt does nothing.
Should I change `mouse_row < cmdline_row` to `mouse_row <= cmdline_row` (maybe remove it altogether?) or is this behavior better?
Probably best to preserve existing behavior of `inputlist()`, so remove the check.

This test is failing in multiple builds:

```
1 FAILED:
Found errors in Test_cscopeWithCscopeConnections():
function RunTheTest[35]..Test_cscopeWithCscopeConnections line 206: Expected '"cs add find help kill reset show' but got 'cs find s main'
```

You can run it locally like this (you might need to install `cscope` ...):

    TEST_FILE=test_cscope.res make oldtest

- Can you explain how this affects https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/7857 ?
- Need to update docs (`:help inputlist()`, at least).

- Before this, `f_inputlist()` used to execute without getting into `state_enter()` but directly calling `safe_vgetc()`. This, I think, made it a blocking function and timers were not processed.
- I introduced a new mode `#` (number) for `struct cmdline_info` which takes input from the commandline but only digits are processed and everything else (alphabets, special chars) is rejected. This is ideal for this scenario and can be extended to implement any new function (e.g. `getnumber()`) in the future which only reads numbers.
- There's no change in `inputlist()` behavior so, `:h inputlist` need not be updated.
Ok, so there's no user-facing enhancement here?
No.
Is this still WIP, or potentially ready for merge?
Oh, I completely forgot about this. I think there was some test that was failing. Let me fix that and rebase.

Commenting out this section solves the [problem](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/8076#issuecomment-383284481):
```viml
" From line 192 in testdir/test_cscope.vim

" Test 19: this should trigger call to cs_print_tags()
" Unclear how to check result though, we just exercise the code.
set cst cscopequickfix=s0
call feedkeys(":cs find s main\<CR>", 't')


```
Or even changing the last line to:
```viml
call feedkeys(":cs find s int\<CR>", 't')
```
@justinmk, I am unsure how to this is related to my PR and how to proceed with it.
cscope was removed, that might unblock this.
This seems superseded by #31525, but maybe some parts of this PR (especially tests) are still useful?
Lots of code and reviews spent on this, but still wondering what problem it solves.

title: Add new type '#' (number) for cmdline and use it in get_number
